title: Who will win the U.S. Senate election for South Carolina in 2020?
preds: Will stick to what I had in August and just up the percentage a bit
The GOP has a slight edge here as Biden is not likely to win the state but people do dislike Graham a lot so he still may lose. The race is a toss up.
Stong support for Trump's agenda in the state.  Higher percentage of African Americans voting Republican.

DT is leading by huge margin. Vote splitting normally does not happen.

'Dirty tricks': Third-party candidate in heated South Carolina Senate race denounces Dem ads - POLITICO

Thu, 29 Oct 2020 14:13:00 GMT

GOP (-7), Dem (+7) I'm adjusting a little bit to meet the crowd and the 538 forecast. A close look at polling on the SC senate race shows a tight race EXCEPT for a NYT poll that gives Grahm a strong lead. The reliance on one high quality poll as the basis of Grahms lead has me concerned. However, I do think most of the polls show a lot of undecided voters who will likely swallow their unfavorable view of Grahm at the last minute and vote for him. Still, I would not be shocked if Harris carried it.
Graham still has an edge here but not by much. If he wins it will be close.
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.

It's close and Graham has run a lousy campaign, but the built in advantage Republicans enjoy will make it hard to dislodge him. Down ballot races will probably be more affected by Harrison's voters than the Senate seat. But you can't count someone who has run such a great campaign totally out. And Graham's character has become difficult to bear. Close! But probably not close enough for the Democrats.
Last few polls have been good for Harrison, and Lou(ser) Dobbs came out against Graham on Fox News during prime time.  I think that will have a small effect, and the race is very close.
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.
This race is tied but I still think the GOP has a slight edge here. However, if Biden wins in a landslide, Harrison could win.
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.

Leaning more heavily towards the Democratic candidate than recent polling would suggest because of the higher enthusiasm as proxied by fundraising in Q3. Overall still a very red state so it would still be a surprise for the Democrats to take the seat.

Little change in polling/support even after huge fundraising numbers for Harrison, most of which came from out-of-state contributors. While Graham's also comes mostly from out-of-state, the state itself is historically Red and Graham should be considered the frontrunner until a change in local sentiment shows itself. The fact the race is even close this late in the year is a miracle in itself, but there just may not be enough support for Harrison in SC to get him the win in November. Worth watching these results on election night though!
Apologies for the spam; testing something.

Even an internal Harrison pollster making all kinds of optimistic assumptions only found him to be at +2: https://jaimeharrison.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/10.16-Poll.pdf
I keep messing this one up, having accidentally submitting the wrong odds twice. So just putting all my chips on Lindsey (double-checking I did it right) and leaving it for the election. Good luck all

Lindsey's problem has been with the right wing of the Republican party.   He is trying to shore up his base after his attacks on Trump in  2016.  The Barrett hearings seem to be helping.   Covid spiking and a  worsening economy will  push in the other direction,  but the timing is good for Graham because it will take a few weeks for the pain to be felt and the voting has already started.

I keep screwing this up. Goodbye to my Brier score. Meant to put chips on GOP.  Polls just came in, looking better now for Lady G: https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/senate/south-carolina/ Had there been early voting starting a few weeks ago, this could’ve been more of a tossup, but South Carolina doesn’t do that

I think Lindsey Grahm is being undervalued on this question. Harrison is a strong candidate and has remarkable fundraising but South Carolina is a heavy lift. As 538 writers point out it is an insanely inelastic state due to the high percentage of evangelicals and racially conservative white voters. Additionally, I have reason to believe that Grahm's unpopularity is leading people to under-report the fact that they will actually hold their nose show up and vote for him. Most of the people who dislike Lindsey in that state, after all, are more to the right of him. Finally, it's a deep red state in an election year so my prior says the candidate that matches the president will do fine.

Harrison has a huge fundraising advantage and suburban women hate Lindsey.

Gadzooks, Graham’s not afraid to say the quiet part out loud, is he?
https://mobile.twitter.com/stevemorris__/status/1314715904131895296
I'm not sure I have a clear view of all the factors so I'm moving toward the crowd.
Base rate from 538 - pushed up in favor of Graham since in a normal election SC skews heavily conservative Question will come down on how different sub-segments of voters come out and vote
Great article at 538 today about why this has tightened: https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/how-did-lindsey-graham-end-up-in-such-a-close-race/

The race has tightened a lot. All polls (6 of them) show dead heat (less than 3% difference in votes). Fivethirtyeight.com is giving too much weightage to opinion polls from July. The momentum is shifting to Democrats. This race could have lots of political ramifications.

AS before, really interesting that The Economist gives Democrats such a high chance. https://projects.economist.com/us-2020-forecast/senate/south-carolina
PredictIt, too: https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/6706/Which-party-will-win-the-US-Senate-election-in-South-Carolina-in-2020

The Supreme Court just ruled that all absentee and mail-in ballots must have a signature from a witness.  Voting has already started, but there is an exception for already case or that are in the mail that are received in the last few days.  Polls have shown -- at least the national polls -- that Democrats intend to vote by mail in much larger numbers than Republicans.   This is a very close election.   Graham has the advantage of incumbency in a state he easily won in the past.   I think there will be some backlash to this ruling, but all in all I think it helps Graham quite a bit.  https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/05/us/supreme-court-south-carolina-absentee-ballots.html

As of this morning (Oct 4), The Economist gives Graham a 64% chance while Fivethirtyeight gives him an 80% chance. Recent developments in the race (the GOP COVID outbreak, the senatorial debate) seem to lean in favor of the Democrats, and are too new to have had their impact detected in polls. I'm therefore a little more bullish on the Democrats than the models, although the prior that a Republican will win South Carolina should be pretty strong.
Interesting that the economist model is so unsure. PredictIt, too: https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/6706/Which-party-will-win-the-US-Senate-election-in-South-Carolina-in-2020

Graham is desperate for cash after his opponent brought in huge loads following Graham's Supreme Court hypocrisy. This is truly a history vs. money election, with the state pretty comfortably red but the blue candidate rolling in dough. Every poll now has them neck and neck at this point in the race. Should be an interesting finish.

Leaning Dem estimating Chairing Judiciary committee will hurt, but maybe more bias.

A conventional South Carolina resident would say that Lindsay Graham being a long time incumbent and in a solid red state that is South Carolina, has much higher chances of winning the Senate seat in 2020 elections. With that being said, however, Harrison "has already spent $22.8 million and has another $15.5 million on the books, compared with $7.8 million spent and $1.9 million in future reservations for the incumbent". A conventional South Carolina resident would say that Lindsay Graham being a longtime incumbent and in a solidly red state that is South Carolina, has a much higher chance of winning the Senate seat in the 2020 elections. However, with that being said, Harrison "has already spent $22.8 million and has another $15.5 million on the books, compared with $7.8 million spent and $1.9 million in future reservations for the incumbent". With such substantial outspending, Harrison's ads have already influenced enough voters to turn a likely Republican win into a close election. FiveThirtyEight puts their polling difference to about 4-6% in favor of Graham, and gives him the odds of 80-20 to win the seat. But there is still enough time for Harrison to close that gap. FiveThirtyEight puts their polling difference to about 4-6% in favor of Graham, and gives him the odds of 80-20 to win the seat. But there is still enough time for Harrison to close that gap.

Going contrary on this one. Polls have them at dead even. The message that Lindsey has spent his time in the national limelight rather than representing SC is gaining some traction.

Race neck and neck again according to recent poll. Graham took a little heat for Trump tapes, with several major Trump supporters accusing him of talking the President into doing the interviews. This is the first major rift we have seen in a while and it couldn't come at a worse time for Graham. If the President latches onto this excuse, Graham will likely lose support, and fast. That, when combined with his challenger's knack for raising loads of money, could spell trouble for Graham's re-election and ultimately the GOP Senate majority. This is by no means a sure thing, but it isn't as insane as it seemed a couple weeks ago.
Last two Quinnipiac polls show Graham and Harrison tied. https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/senate/sc/south_carolina_senate_graham_vs_harrison-7083.html

While polls show this has been close, I think the crowd underestimates the odds of Graham winning:
1) The Democratic candidate doesn't have a great resume for this office, having never been elected to any office. 
2) Zero statewide Democratic officeholders. This is a huge institutional issue creating an uphill battle for Dems running for a statewide office.
3) The recent history of SC elections, as well as the Cook partisan lean of the state, which is R+8. The 15% comes from the closeness in polls, as well as the fact that, let's face it (we're all adults here, right?), we all know Graham is highly vulnerable to an October Surprise in a conservative state like SC: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/October_surprise
This race is razor thin. Could go either way with a slight edge for the democrats still

I have grown up in South Carolina, and from anecdotal experience Democrats just don't get elected, not outside of Charleston's House candidate. However, polling numbers at 538 put it at only a 3% differential between the two candidates, so it would be foolish to completely rule out an upset. While I have yet to see an ad run by Harrison (the Democratic candidate), negative ads run by Graham (the Republican candidate) indicate he has connections with Hillary Clinton and Nancy Pelosi - clearly this is someone with connections, and Graham's emphatic support of Trump the past four years somewhat ties the two elections, both of which appear to be in a relative dead heat per current polling numbers. As for a third party candidate winning, I have yet to hear of one, so I'll believe it when I see it. Update: After researching further, I think I was mistaken about the competitiveness of Harrison's campaign - he is an impressive candidate, an Orangeburg, SC native who went on to graduate from Yale (does not happen too often down here) and has worked very high profile positions, most notably as a lobbyist for the Podesta Group, an organization with strong ties to many nationally relevant Democrats. This has led to a well funded campaign - from April to June 2020, Lindsey Graham (Republican) raised a strong $8.4 million for his re-election campaign. The challenger, Jamie Harrison (Democrat) raised an astounding $14 million over the same two months. Jamie Harrison is likely the strongest Democratic challenger to this Senate seat in a long time, and Lindsey Graham may be at his most vulnerable - even the most staunch of Southern Republicans can't help but make fun of his weasly ways. I still favor Graham because of two things: one, he is a Republican in SC, and two, change rarely happens in the Deep South. But I have changed the ratio from 90/10 to 70/30 - I will be keeping a close eye on this, and may push it even further if Harrison's campaign continues to flourish.
Lindsey Graham has been in the SC Senate since 2003. Graham has a strong backing including President Trump, SC has historically been a red state. So i believe that this trend will continue

However, polling numbers at 538 put it at only a 3% differential between the two candidates, so it would be foolish to completely rule out an upset. While I have yet to see an ad run by Harrison (the Democratic candidate), negative ads run by Graham (the Republican candidate) indicate he has connections with Hillary Clinton and Nancy Pelosi - clearly this is someone with connections, and Graham's emphatic support of Trump the past four years somewhat ties the two elections, both of which appear to be in a relative dead heat per current polling numbers. As for a third party candidate winning, I have yet to hear of one, so I'll believe it when I see it.
Harrison, the Dem, is performing very well, but so is Trump, in recent polls.  I'm weighing a coattail effect for the Rep.

Republicans pretty well ingrained in South Carolina.

as @aurbital already mentioned he is 3rd term candidate and the state is since 80s republican. He is doing well at the moment with the crisis for blm and C-19 so I would think the chances rising for him to win, as I don't really see an candidate from democratic party to compete . Some unknown factor is how bad the president might interfere and what other unpredictable events might happen. As Lindsay is not much of a fan for Trump it could be less counting.
Trump's coattails may carry Graham over the line.
Lindsy Graham has had one close election in 2002 when he won by only 10 points.

Lindsey Graham is already a 3rd term senator, voters in the state would have to be REALLY unhappy with him and/or with Republicans to choose his opponent. His re-election bid will be closely tied to how well Trump does in the state and currently Trump is leading polls with at least 5 points -- not the stellar lead one would expect from South Carolina but not surprising given the national correlation of Trump unhappiness with COVID. That said, for presidential elections South Carolina has voted Republican since Reagan 1980 -- the people who live there likely identify themselves as a "red" state by now, so most likely Trump will win the state and Lindsey Graham will keep his Senate seat.
Race is closer than normally anticipated, Presidential campaign will impact ticket down voting.

South Carolina has alway been a solidly red state. But Lindsey Graham is increasingly off-balance and unpopular and popular distaste for Trump will have fallout for him. In addition, the Blacks Lives Matter protests have turned up the heat on Lindsey and South Carolina in general.
Unlikely that Graham will lose given incumbency.
Based on 538 recent polls and 270 to win Senate map. Seems pretty safe for Graham but on the other hand national polling and the presidency lean the other way so that lowers confidence a bit.
SC is a bright and beautiful red state.
It’s my belief that Lindsey Graham’s tenure is over due to his conflicting messages and broad support of President Trump and his disastrous policies.
Close, leaning to incumbent.  However, the challenger is raising good money and surging in the polls.  I'm betting how Trump goes, this Senate seat goes.
SC has been a deep red state for some time and the demographic make up of the state has not changed much over the last 20 years.

I would have said an easy one for GOP - but to be frank there are a lot of ppl that are well and truly pissed, so it could well be much closer. Will have to keep an eye on events and party shenanigans to gauge this outcome

Jaime Harrison says it much better than I could: “...we are suffering here in South Carolina. People literally are dying because they don’t have health care, and this guy isn’t lifting a finger. But because he’s trying to rebuild his image in the eyes of the president, he will do and say anything.” Lindsey Graham changes his positions and his morals whenever he thinks it will benefit him. He went from opposing Trump in 2016 to being one of his biggest apologists and favored golfing buddies over the past 4 years.  Harrison can run a flawless campaign, raise a ton of cash, and peel off moderate voters, but I think Graham will sweet talk enough South Carolinian’s into voting for him to squeak out a win. https://www.esquire.com/news-politics/politics/a33611147/jaime-harrison-interview-lindsey-graham-south-carolina/

Graham is not in a good spot by any means, especially as an incumbent. However, he has a ton of name recognition (for better or worse), is running in a pretty reliably red state, and has not been down in any poll reported on 538 (though they have all been close in recent weeks). Easily could go either way, but I would lean toward the more boring, predictable outcome here in favor of a dark horse game changer unless Graham gets undermined by the president in the coming weeks (could happen) or some large scandal occurs (also definitely a possibility).

The atmosphere is ripe for Lindsay Graham to lose. He is way underwater with suburban women and urban areas. He could well lose even though the state leans Republican. Polls have Graham tied with Harrison for weeks now. It is going to be close.
